Either they're going to be in the money within intrinsic value, or they're going to be out of the money and worth nothing at expiration. So options that are out of the money are all extrinsic value, which is time value and volatility. Essentially, those are the two components for extrinsic value. When we look at intrinsic value, that's simply how far in the money something is. So for the call side, again, notice this shaded area. So this looks like 2526 cents of extrinsic value left in these options. Something like that. Okay, deeper in the money you go, the less extrinsic value you have. Now further out of the money you go, it's actually the same thing. And why? It's because the options are cheaper and cheaper and cheaper. There's only 25 cents of extrinsic value in these 105s. They're just very, very cheap. Why does that matter? Well, because when theta decays, the theta decay curve is highest or options that are at the money because there's the most extrinsic value. And theta decay actually slows down as you go deeper in the money because there's less extrinsic value. And theta decay slows down when you go further out of the money because there's less extrinsic value. That is as a gross dollar amount. The last thing I'll say is the further out of the money you go, the lower your delta is. And for those that don't know, delta is simply the rate of change of premium for one point move in the underlying. So what that means is if GameStop goes up by a dollar, these 42 calls have a delta of 24. So if GameStop goes up by a dollar, this premium will change by 24 cents. And if you're further in the money, again, more expensive still, but now if GameStop goes a dollar instead of seeing 24 bucks, you're going to see 80 bucks, 80 cents times a hundred. That's the multiplier for options contracts. So it's a bit of a balance. That's the cool part about options. You get to set them up to be exactly what you want. If you expect a big, big massive move and you're super convicted, you can go further out of the money and play the expansion of those deltas. Or you can play a little more conservatively like I typically do. I would go slightly in the money, pay up for the options. I would still have a management plan in place. I at no point would expect to just hold these into expiration because then you do run the risk of losing more money if these fall out of the money. I wouldn't want that to happen. But you can get stuff that's in the money, get a better delta for dollar move based on what you put in a little more expensive.
